text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits the revised IRM 5.12.6, Federal Tax Liens, Appeals Processes Involving Liens.

Editorial changes made throughout to update references and terminology; to correct formatting issues; and to revise wording for clarity, eliminate unnecessary or duplicate verbiage, and comply with current writing standards. Material changes are noted below.

IRM 5.12.6.3. Shortened title. Added passport legislation provision to items required in CDP notice, inserted paragraph from 5.12.6.3.6 about contact information on notice, and referenced 5.12.6.3.5 for documents to include with notice.

IRM 5.12.6.3.5. Changed title to reﬂect the revised content. Moved certain paragraphs between and 5.12.6.3.6 to better align information. Added note about the terminology used in relation to the CDP notice. Restructured paragraphs for ﬂow. Clariﬁed role of ALS in CDP notice process. Incorporated information from 5.12.6.3.6 about inserts with Letter 3172. Moved information about entity types to new subsection 5.12.6.3.5.1. Added exception for NFTLs ﬁled against estates for § 6321 assessments.

IRM 5.12.6.3.6. Changed title. Moved certain paragraphs between this and 5.12.6.3.5 to better align information. Restructured paragraphs to clarify calculations of mailing and response time frames. Removed unnecessary information about process for manually ﬁling NFTLs. Moved information about Letter 3171 to 5.12.6.3.6.2 and paragraph about contact information to 5.12.6.3.
IRM 5.12.6.3.6.1. New subsection for special address considerations, including sending the CDP notice to co-obligors at other addresses and estate ﬁduciaries.
IRM 5.12.6.3.7. Moved information about co-obligors to 5.12.6.3.5.1. Restructured paragraphs for ﬂow and clarity. Moved paragraphs about substitute and duplicate notices to 5.12.6.3.9.

IRM 5.12.6.3.11. Updated title, restructured paragraphs, clariﬁed notice issues for successor-in- interest situations, and revised wording to make consistent with current special condition NFTL procedures.

IRM 5.12.6.3.14. Changed title. Rearranged information and converted withdrawal guidance to table. Replaced details about ﬁle preparation with reference to applicable IRM on appeals. Removed paragraph about Fast Track Mediation as obsolete guidance.

5.12.6.3.16: Moved Note under (2) to separate paragraph and combined similar paragraphs. Condensed paragraph on combat zone freeze to make more succinct. Inserted instruction on reversing the TC 971 AC 252.

IRM 5.12.6.3.17. Clariﬁed types of returned mail. Inserted reminder for notices addressed to secondary taxpayers. Restructured paragraphs and converted some information to chart. Added note on handling notices returned annotated with multiple reasons.
IRM 5.12.6.3.18. Shortened title. Restructured and rearranged paragraphs.
This material supersedes IRM 5.12.6 dated October 14, 2013.
SBSE and W&I Collection, Centralized Lien Operation, and Appeals

Involving Liens

) Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) ﬁlings and requests related to the the ﬁled NFTL, including discharge of property from the federal tax lien and and withdrawal of the NFTL, are generally subject to review of the Appeals (
) Purpose: This IRM provides guidance on the appeal rights afforded regarding NFTL ﬁlings and the lien program. (
) Audience: This IRM is used by IRS personnel that request NFTLs and/or handle requests related to the federal tax lien. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy. Small Business/Sell-Employed Division (SBSE) (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy is the program office responsible for seeing the lien program and maintaining this IRM. (

) Primary Stakeholders: SBSE Collection and Wage & Investment (W&I) lection. Other functions that are affected by, or have input to, the include Chief Counsel, Appeals, and the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS). (
) Program Goals: Provide policy and procedural guidance to ensure appeal rights regarding lien processes are observed. (
) In

, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) implemented a Collection Program (CAP) to provide an administrative appeal option to taxpayers for certain collection actions. Although never speciﬁcally being mandated by statute, the CAP program has continued since then and has expanded in scope through policy changes following legislative acts such as the ing and Reform Act of
(RRA
) As part of RRA
, IRC §

was enacted to give taxpayers a right to a lection Due Process (CDP) hearing with the Appeals office when an NFTL ﬁled on their tax liability. Taxpayers were also given the right to go to court Appeals’ determination under CDP, a right not afforded under CAP. (
) Taxpayers have the right to appeal the proposed ﬁling of an NFTL under and the right to appeal the actual ﬁling of the NFTL under CDP or CAP. (
) The policies in this IRM are based primarily on the following: • IRC §
, Notice and opportunity for hearing upon ﬁling of notice lien • Treasury Regulation §
, Notice and opportunity for upon ﬁling of notice of federal tax lien • IRC §
, Appeals dispute resolution procedures (
) The Director, Collection Policy is responsible for overseeing policy and dures regarding lien actions and the associated appeal rights. (

) Employees that request NFTL ﬁlings are responsible for providing accurate formation for CDP notices. Employees manually preparing NFTLs are responsible for ensuring CDP notices are properly issued. (
) Employees authorized to make determinations regarding speciﬁc lien are responsible for ensuring CAP rights have been provided appropriately. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Taxpayers have the right to appeal the proposed ﬁling of an NFTL under and the right to appeal the actual ﬁling of the NFTL under CDP or CAP.
Employees authorized to make determinations regarding speciﬁc lien actions are responsible for ensuring CAP rights have been provided appropriately.

The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) is required by law to conduct an annual audit to determine whether CDP notices issued by the IRS comply with the requirements of IRC § 6320.

) Taxpayers have two ways to appeal certain collection actions to the IRS of Appeals: Rights • Collection Due Process (CDP) or Equivalent Hearing • Collection Appeals Program (CAP) (
) Collection personnel need to explain CAP and CDP appeal rights to throughout the collection process and answer questions taxpayers may regarding their right to appeal. See IRM
, Informing Taxpayers of Appeal Rights. The guidance in this IRM pertains to the appeal rights for NFTL ﬁling and other actions related to the federal tax lien. (
) Taxpayers may also contact the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) for tance. See IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service , and IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria. (
) Under IRC §

, the Internal Revenue Service must notify taxpayers in writing of their right to a CDP hearing with the Office of Appeals the ﬁrst tax period is included on an NFTL. The written notiﬁcation must be given ﬁve (
) business days of the ﬁling of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien. When taxpayer timely requests a CDP hearing, the taxpayer has a right to review of the Appeals determination.

regarding the potential revocation, denial, or limitation of passports of individuals with seriously delinquent tax (

) A CDP notice must be separately issued to each taxpayer named on the at their respective last known address. In most situations, the address shown on the NFTL is where the notice should be sent, but be mindful of circum- stances where additional addresses are needed. The entity type can provide clues to identify these situations. (

) Individuals. When the NFTL is for a jointly-owed liability, each co-obligor spouse, ex-spouse) must be sent the notice in a separate envelope to their respective last known address. Be alert for situations, such as or separation, where the co-obligors live at different addresses. (

) Partnership. The notice must be sent to the partnership’s address and rately to any general partners listed on the NFTL at their respective When mailing addresses are not available for the general partners’ and the place of employment is not the partnership, attempt to provide the notice during face to face contact with the co-obligors. (
) Limited Liability Company (LLC). Prior to requesting the NFTL, determine whether the LLC or the single member owner is the liable taxpayer. See IRM

, Collecting from Limited Liability Companies. Send the notice to the known address of the liable taxpayer. If there are questions as to whom be identiﬁed on the NFTL, contact Advisory or Area Counsel. Reminder: The NFTL should not show both the name of the LLC and single member owner. (
) Consolidated Group. A consolidated group is an affiliated group of corpora- tions connected through stock ownership in a parent-subsidiary relationship deﬁned in IRC §

The affiliated group may elect to ﬁle a consolidated income tax return. In such situations the common parent and all the ies must be listed on the NFTL and also on the CDP notice; however, the notice should not be mailed to the subsidiaries. The common parent is the entity with the right to participate in a CDP hearing on behalf of subsidiary members of the consolidated group. If there are questions as to whom be listed on the NFTL, contact Advisory or Area Counsel.

) The Automated Collection System (ACS) and ICS interact with the Centralized Authorization File (CAF) to identify POAs authorized to receive notices. ACS and ICS systemically send POA information to ALS when an NFTL request includes one of the tax periods covered by the authorization. The POA notice is then systemically generated by ALS and printed and mailed at CPS. (

) There are situations where the POA information is not systemically down- loaded to ALS or additional action is needed to generate the notices, but not limited to, the following situations. • The NFTL request is rejected. When this happens, the POA information is not loaded to ALS and a notice to the POA is not generated. The POA information must be resubmitted to ALS. • A POA is identiﬁed but their information had not yet posted to the Cen- tralized Authorization File (CAF) when the NFTL is requested. The POA information must be manually input to ALS. • The secondary taxpayer on a joint liability has a different POA than the primary taxpayer. A nominee, alter ego, or transferee named on a special condition NFTL is not entitled to CDP rights for the ﬁling. (See Q-B
in Treasury Regulation

).) A successor-in-interest named on a special condition NFTL may be entitled to CDP rights for the ﬁling. If the IRS has made a determination that the taxpayer has ceased to exist and the taxpayer has not been given CDP rights for the assessments listed on the special condition NFTL, then the successor-in-interest listed on the NFTL is entitled to CDP rights. In these circumstances, the successor-in-interest is primarily liable for the tax and steps into the shoes of the taxpayer. If these circumstances are not present, the successor-in-interest is not entitled to CDP rights for the special condition NFTL ﬁling.

) The Collection Appeals Program (CAP) was implemented to provide or third parties with an opportunity to have collection actions reviewed by an impartial party outside the Collection function. See IRM
, Collection Appeals Program (CAP), for additional details. Taxpayers should be advised their CAP rights throughout the collection process. See IRM
, Taxpayers of Their Appeal Rights. (

) Collection actions appealable under CAP are NFTL ﬁlings, levies, seizures, and installment agreement (denials, modiﬁcations or terminations). In CAP can be used to appeal other lien actions including the denial of a for a withdrawal of NFTL, discharge, subordination, or nonattachment. Refer IRM
, Withdrawal of Notice of Federal Tax Lien, and IRM
, Lien Related Certiﬁcates for further information. (

) CAP is available before or after the NFTL ﬁling. Taxpayers can dispute the proposed or actual ﬁling of the NFTL. CAP is also available to taxpayers and third parties named as nominees, alter egos, transferees, or successors-in- interest, to dispute the ﬁling of a special condition NFTL. See IRM Special Condition NFTL Situations, and IRM
, Appeal Rights for Special Condition NFTLs, for details. (

) A determination to deny an application for withdrawal, discharge, subordina- tion, or nonattachment may be communicated to the applicant in writing or verbally. Denials communicated verbally should be followed up with written tiﬁcation. In either instance, an explanation of the right to appeal must be provided to the applicant. Pub
, Collection Appeal Rights, may be used this purpose. (

) If a CAP appeal is requested for the denial of a lien certiﬁcate request, the taxpayer that your decision must be discussed with your immediate visor before beginning the Collection Appeals process.

In the fax transmittal or email, include your name, email address, telephone number, fax number, as well as the taxpayer’s name and telephone number, and, if applicable, the POA’s name and telephone number. Also, indicate the date of the group manager’s conference and the group manager’s email address..

Any narrative statement included on the fax transmittal or email must be limited to neutral, factual statements regarding actions taken and docu- mented in the case history without any discussion of the strengths and weaknesses of the taxpayer’s appeal. The manager must ensure this requirement is met and that no prohibited ex parte communications are included before approving the transmittal of the case to Appeals. Refer to IRM
, Communications with Appeals.
) The Appeals organization tries to resolve CAP cases within ﬁve (
) business days of the receipt of the case by the Settlement Officer (SO). More complex CAP cases are normally resolved within ﬁfteen (
) business days. (

) If a taxpayer presents new information to Appeals that the revenue officer has not considered, Appeals may ask the revenue officer to review and comment on the information, in accordance with the ex parte requirements. See IRM
, CAP Process. (

) When the ﬁling of the NFTL is the subject of the appeal, further NFTL action is generally withheld unless appropriate to protect the government’s interests. The group manager must concur with the planned action during the appeal. Prior to taking further NFTL action, check with Appeals to determine if they have any new information from the taxpayer that may affect the decision. Refer to IRM
, Communications with Appeals. (
) Appeals will inform both the taxpayer and Collection of their decision as soon as possible within the ﬁve (
) business day requirement. Decisions by Appeals are binding on the taxpayer and Collection. (
) If there is concern or disagreement with respect to a decision reached by Appeals refer to IRM
, Disagreement with Appeals Decisions.
